properties.title: Powershap: A Power-full Shapley Feature Selection Method
properties.abstract: Feature selection is a crucial step in developing robust and powerful machine learning models. Feature selection techniques can be divided into two categories: filter and wrapper methods. While wrapper methods commonly result in strong predictive performances, they suffer from a large computational complexity and therefore take a significant amount of time to complete, especially when dealing with high-dimensional feature sets. Alternatively, filter methods are considerably faster, but suffer from several other disadvantages, such as (i) requiring a threshold value, (ii) many filter methods not taking into account inter-correlation between features, and (iii) ignoring feature interactions with the model. To this end, we present powershap, a novel wrapper feature selection method, which leverages statistical hypothesis testing and power calculations in combination with Shapley values for quick and intuitive feature selection. Powershap is built on the core assumption that an informative feature will have a larger impact on the prediction compared to a known random feature. Benchmarks and simulations show that powershap outperforms other filter methods with predictive performances on par with wrapper methods while being significantly faster, often even reaching half or a third of the execution time. As such, powershap provides a competitive and quick algorithm that can be used by various models in different domains. Furthermore, powershap is implemented as a plug-and-play and open-source sklearn component, enabling easy integration in conventional data science pipelines. User experience is even further enhanced by also providing an automatic mode that automatically tunes the hyper-parameters of the powershap algorithm, allowing to use the algorithm without any configuration needed.

properties.description: To develop Powershap, a novel feature selection method leveraging statistical hypothesis testing and power calculations with Shapley values for efficient feature selection.
Powershap combines wrapper feature selection methodologies with statistical hypothesis testing and Shapley values.
Powershap outperforms other filter methods, providing predictive performance competitive with wrapper methods and improved execution time.
Powershap allows quick integration as an open-source sklearn component for diverse models and domains.
Open-source component for easy integration in data science pipelines with automatic hyper-parameter tuning.
Compared with filter, wrapper, and SHAP-based methods on synthetic and real-world datasets, showing faster execution and reliable feature selection.
Automatic mode optimizes iterations using power calculations, reducing the need for extensive tuning.
Benchmarks conducted without tuning specific features; dependency on choice of machine learning models could influence results.

properties.name: Feature Selection Importance
properties.description: Feature selection is important for reducing feature dimensionality, increasing model performance, enhancing computational efficiency, and improving model robustness.

properties.name: Filter Methods
properties.description: Filter methods are model-independent, fast, but have disadvantages such as ignoring inter-correlation between features and requiring thresholds.

properties.name: Wrapper Methods
properties.description: Wrapper methods consider feature interactions but are computationally expensive.

properties.name: Shapley Values
properties.description: SHAP values provide model-agnostic explanations and are popular despite some limitations.

properties.name: BorutaSHAP
properties.description: Combines the Boruta algorithm using Shapley values, limited to tree-based models.

properties.name: Shapicant
properties.description: Inspired by permutation importance, adapted to use Shapley values for non-parameter estimation.

nodes.label: Interpretation
nodes.text: Powershap is a novel wrapper feature selection method that combines statistical hypothesis testing, power calculations, and Shapley values for efficient feature selection.

nodes.label: Implication
nodes.text: The method offers predictive performance comparable to other wrapper methods but with reduced computational requirements.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.text: Wrapper methods, including Powershap, depend on the model used and could suffer from modeling issues.

nodes.label: Interpretation
nodes.text: Powershap uses an Explain component to add a single known random feature and analyzes its average impact using Shapley values.

nodes.label: Implication
nodes.text: This allows Powershap to statistically compare the impact of real features to a random feature.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.text: The approach's reliance on statistical tests can be influenced by the number of iterations.

nodes.label: Interpretation
nodes.text: The 'automatic mode' in Powershap allows for the optimization of iterations necessary for ensuring desired statistical power.

nodes.label: Implication
nodes.text: This makes Powershap a more user-friendly tool without extensive setup.

nodes.label: Limitation
nodes.text: Anticonservative estimation of p-values might require larger datasets to ensure robustness.

properties.statement: Informative features will have a statistically significant larger impact on the prediction compared to a known random feature.
properties.null_hypothesis: The impact of a random feature is not more significant than the impact of a tested feature.
properties.alternative_hypothesis: The impact of the tested feature is greater than that of a random feature.

properties.name: powershap_algorithm
components: Explain component: Trains multiple models with different random seeds and subsets, each including a random feature, and calculates average feature impact using Shapley values.
Core powershap component: Compares impacts of original features statistically to a random feature, selecting informative features based on statistical hypothesis testing.

automatic_mode.optimization_goal: Optimize number of iterations using statistical power calculations to balance runtime and feature selection quality.

properties.description: In data mining and machine learning, the goal is to extract and discover knowledge from data. Feature selection is crucial for developing robust models by reducing high dimensionality and addressing the unknown relevance of features.

Ignoring the challenges of high dimensionality and feature irrelevance leads to modeling obstacles like sparse data, overfitting, and the curse of dimensionality. Thus, feature selection is frequently applied to enhance model performance and computational efficiency.

Current filter and wrapper feature selection methods come with trade-offs. Wrapper methods, while strong in predictive performance, are computationally intensive. Filter methods, although faster, have limitations such as requiring a threshold value, neglecting inter-correlation between features, and ignoring feature interactions with the model.

Powershap is a novel feature selection method leveraging Shapley values, surpassing filter methods in speed and performing on par with wrapper methods in terms of predictive accuracy on benchmark datasets.
Powershap combines statistical hypothesis testing, power calculations, and Shapley values to assess feature importance.
Features are selected by comparing their Shapley value impacts against those of a known random feature.
Automatic mode optimizes parameters using statistical power calculations to determine adequate iteration counts, aiming for efficient yet robust feature selection.
Performance is heavily reliant on the choice of underlying machine learning models, influencing feature selection quality.
In datasets with high dimensionality and high ratio of informative features, the default setup may struggle due to model underfitting risks.
Many hyperparameters were set to defaults without extensive tuning, possibly affecting benchmark impartiality.
Convergence mode allows recursive execution to discover additional informative features in complex datasets.
Backward selection can be added post-powershap execution to further refine selected feature subsets.

nodes.label: Permutation importance: a corrected feature importance measure.
